Package jrtr

Class MeshData

  • java.lang.Object
    • jrtr.MeshData
  • public class MeshData
extends java.lang.Object
    This class represents a geometric object that is stored in a mesh structure. Each vertix knows its adjacent vertices, edges and faces
    Author:
    CGG\indermuehle

    • Method Detail

      • createMesh

        private void createMesh​(java.util.List<MeshData.Vertex> vertexList,
                        int[] i)
        Helper-Function for the Loop subdivision. Should be always called after a subdivision so that the Winged Edge Structure and the VertexData are updated!
        Parameters:
        vertexList - List of all vertices, does not need to have edges, the edges are assigned later to vertices
        i - Index-List, defines how the vertices are combined into a triangle mesh

      • createMesh

        public void createMesh​(VertexData data)
        Constructs a winged edge structure from a vertex data. The mesh has to fulfill two requirements: 1. The mesh must completely consist of triangles 2. The mesh must have no borders, e.g. each edge must belong to exactly two triangles
        Parameters:
        data - the VertexData

      • createMeshStructure

        private void createMeshStructure​(int[] i,
                                 int p)

      • createVertexData

        private void createVertexData()
        Converts the mesh structure into a vertexData and stores it as this.vertexData

      • getFaceNormals

        public float[] getFaceNormals()
        (DEPRECATED) Creates a list of faceNormals that can be used in a vertexData. For each vertex in a face, the x, y and z coordinates of the face normal is added to the array
        Returns:
        array containing face normals

      • getVertexData

        public VertexData getVertexData()

      • findEdge

        private MeshData.Edge findEdge​(int i1,
                               int i2)
        Finds the edge that conntects the given vertices. If no such edge exists, null is returned
        Parameters:
        i1 - the index in vertexTable of the first vertex
        i2 - the index in vertexTable of the second vertex
        Returns:
        the edge that conntects the two vertices or null

      • findEdges

        private java.util.List<MeshData.Edge> findEdges​(MeshData.Vertex v)
        Finds all edges connecting the given vertex with other vertices
        Parameters:
        v - the vertex
        Returns:
        all edges the vertex belongs to

      • findVertices

        private java.util.List<MeshData.Vertex> findVertices​(MeshData.Vertex v)
        Finds all vertices the given vertex is connected to by an edge
        Parameters:
        v - the vertex
        Returns:
        all directly connected vertices

      • findEdges

        private java.util.List<MeshData.Edge> findEdges​(MeshData.Face f)
        Finds all edges that are part of the face and returns them in counterclockwise order, starting with the edge defined in f itself
        Parameters:
        f - the face
        Returns:
        all edges of the face in counterclockwise order

      • findVertices

        private java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> findVertices​(MeshData.Face f)
        Finds all vertices of a face and returns them in counterclockwise order, starting with the starting vertex of the edge defined in f itself. This does not depend on the orientation of the edge, as it will be oriented to be counterclockwise
        Parameters:
        f - the face
        Returns:
        the vertices in counterclockwise order

      • loop

        public void loop()
        Subdivide with the Loop-algorithm. This results in a smoother shape that consists of triangles
